repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fix #2047 

Hi,
first off all, many thanks to the maintainers and the contributors of this cool project !

I tried to address the nice idea opened (and also possibly forgotten) a (very) long time ago on issue #2047 ^^ (yes 2016, indeed...).

Is the idea still interesting ? I tried to check if the latter would clash with more recent pull requests/issues, but found nothing so far. Why not spare us a few characters while piping shell command to the buffer ?

Thanks for your attention in advance to this pull request !

comment_data.body: the comment is out of place now?

these tests would fit best in `test/functional/vimscript/system_spec.lua` , here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/28f1f65bb30768db3423dc6eb39b2d75dfaba326/test/functional/vimscript/system_spec.lua#L632
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,4 +52,22 @@ describe('Ex cmds', function()
     eq(2, funcs.exists(':defer'))
     eq('defer', funcs.fullcommand('defer'))
   end)
+
+  it(':.! should pipe line buffer to &shell', function()

comment_data.body:
can use `[[` to avoid needing to escape stuff
```suggestion
      insert([[find . 'src' -maxdepth 0 -type d;\necho 'hello world';]])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,4 +52,22 @@ describe('Ex cmds', function()
     eq(2, funcs.exists(':defer'))
     eq('defer', funcs.fullcommand('defer'))
   end)
+
+  it(':.! should pipe line buffer to &shell', function()
+    if not helpers.has_powershell() then
+      insert('find . \'src\' -maxdepth 0 -type d')
+      command(':.!')
+      local res = curbuf_contents()
+      eq(res, '.\nsrc')
+    end
+  end)
+
+  it(':%! should pipe buffer to &shell', function()
+    if not helpers.has_powershell() then
+      insert('find . \'src\' -maxdepth 0 -type d;\necho \'hello world\';')

comment_data.body: ideally we'd also have a powershell-specific assertion here, in a `else`

comment_data.body:
a small hint is high-leverage
```suggestion
    if (strlen(newcmd) == 0 && p_sh != NULL) {  // ":range!" without command pipes to 'shell'.
```
I think I did not change this, but I will double check the position in the diffs.
Right, I will move them here ! Thanks for pointing me to this file.

comment_data.body: Agreed, this is done.
Quite sure I did not change this now, I added some code below.

```suggestion
			program {filter}. If {filter} is empty, use previous
			{filter} program, or 'shell' by default.
```

similar for the other case below
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -539,29 +539,37 @@ with ".".  Vim does not recognize a comment (starting with '"') after the
 
 							*!*
 !{motion}{filter}	Filter {motion} text lines through the external
-			program {filter}.
+			program {filter}. If {filter} is empty, use previously
+			{filter} program. {filter} is initially set to 'shell'
+			by default on startup.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			{filter} (or 'shell' by default).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -539,29 +539,37 @@ with ".".  Vim does not recognize a comment (starting with '"') after the
 
 							*!*
 !{motion}{filter}	Filter {motion} text lines through the external
-			program {filter}.
+			program {filter}. If {filter} is empty, use previously
+			{filter} program. {filter} is initially set to 'shell'
+			by default on startup.
 
 							*!!*
 !!{filter}		Filter [count] lines through the external program
-			{filter}.
+			program {filter}. If {filter} is empty, use previously
+			{filter} program. {filter} is initially set to 'shell'
+			by default on startup.
 
 							*v_!*
 {Visual}!{filter}	Filter the highlighted lines through the external
-			program {filter} (for {Visual} see |Visual-mode|).
+			program {filter} (for {Visual} see |Visual-mode|). If
+			{filter} is empty, use previously {filter} program.
+			{filter} is initially set to 'shell' by default on
+			startup.
 
 :{range}![!]{filter} [!][arg]				*:range!*
 			Filter {range} lines through the external program
-			{filter}.  Vim replaces the optional bangs with the
-			latest given command and appends the optional [arg].
-			Vim saves the output of the filter command in a
+			{filter}. If no {filter} program is given, the latter

comment_data.body:
Mentioning "on startup" in all of these docs is somewhat confusing and definitely unnecessary since it's an implementation detail. It's merely "the default".

```suggestion
• |:range!| pipes by default to |'shell'| if a {filter} external
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -230,6 +230,10 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained an "overlap" option to
   return such ranges even if they started before the specified position.
 
+• |:range!| now pipe by default to |'shell'| on startup if a {filter} external

comment_data.body:
This is confusing to mention in the news since it's not new. Users can find the details by visiting the docs.

```suggestion
  program is not given.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -230,6 +230,10 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained an "overlap" option to
   return such ranges even if they started before the specified position.
 
+• |:range!| now pipe by default to |'shell'| on startup if a {filter} external
+  program is not given. But if given, the latter is remembered.

comment_data.body:
Options don't need `|`.

```suggestion
  |:range!| pipes by default to 'shell'.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -477,6 +477,7 @@ Commands:
   |:wincmd| accepts a count.
   `:write!` does not show a prompt if the file was updated externally.
   |:=| does not accept |ex-flags|. With an arg it is equivalent to |:lua=|
+  |:range!| pipe by default to |'shell'| on startup.

comment_data.body: what about the other `prevcmd_is_set` case? can that be usefully handled with this new feature, or it doesn't make sense?
xstrdup ?
xstrdup ?
seems like a strange place for this to live. there's already a `if (addr_count == 0) {` check on line 1060/1076 below, and it has an `else{}` block.
This is now corrected.
This is now corrected.
This is now corrected.

If I understood properly the other (former) case, it involves also the `:!` and not the `:{range}!`. Hence, if we still want the error `No previous command` on user input `:!!` we should not change it, but I may very possibly be wrong.

brackets indicate optional args, in the docs.
```suggestion
!{motion}[filter]	Filter {motion} text lines through the external
```

 							*!*
 !{motion}{filter}	Filter {motion} text lines through the external

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			program [filter]. [filter] defaults to previously used
			filter (if any) or 'shell'.
```

@@ -540,29 +540,36 @@ with ".".  Vim does not recognize a comment (starting with '"') after the
 
 							*!*
 !{motion}{filter}	Filter {motion} text lines through the external
-			program {filter}.
+			program {filter}. If {filter} is empty, use previous
+			{filter} program, or 'shell' by default.

comment_data.body:
to avoid depending on `python3`, it could use `nvim` as a filter?

```suggestion
      insert([[print('foo')]])
      feed('!wnvim -l -<CR>')  -- Executes "print('foo')" using Nvim Lua.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -691,4 +692,95 @@ describe('shell :!', function()
     feed('<CR>')
     helpers.expect_exit(command, 'qall!')
   end)
+
+  it(':.! should pipe line buffer to &shell only replacing the current line', function()
+    if is_os('win') then
+      -- Output of pwsh is lengthy.
+      -- Do not check the full string which is environment dependent
+      -- but the presence of critical words.
+      helpers.set_shell_powershell(true)
+      insert([[echo 'Hi, coconut!';
+exec zsh;]])
+      feed('gg')
+      command(':.!')
+      local found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'Hi, coconut!')
+      neq(found, nil)
+      found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'exec zsh;')
+      neq(found, nil)
+    else
+      insert([[find . 'src' -maxdepth 0 -type d;
+ls]])
+      feed('gg');
+      command(':.!')
+      local res = curbuf_contents()
+      eq(res, [[.
+src
+ls]])
+    end
+  end)
+
+  it(':%! should pipe buffer to &shell replacing the entire buffer', function()
+    if is_os('win') then
+      -- Output of pwsh is lengthy.
+      -- Do not check the full string which is environment dependent
+      -- but the presence of critical words.
+      helpers.set_shell_powershell(true)
+      insert([[dir;
+echo 'Hi, vimers!';]])
+      command(':%!')
+      local found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'Hi, vimers!')
+      neq(found, nil)
+      found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'Directory')
+      neq(found, nil)
+      found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'neovim')
+      neq(found, nil)
+    else
+      insert([[find . 'src' -maxdepth 0 -type d;
+echo 'hello world';]])
+      command(':%!')
+      local res = curbuf_contents()
+      eq(res, [[.
+src
+hello world]])
+    end
+  end)
+
+  it('! should filter motion to &shell by default on startup', function()
+    if is_os('win') then
+      helpers.set_shell_powershell(true)
+      insert([[echo 'Hi, coconut!';
+exec zsh;]])
+      feed('gg!w<CR>')
+      local found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'Hi, coconut!')
+      neq(found, nil)
+      found = string.find(curbuf_contents(), 'exec zsh;')
+      neq(found, nil)
+    else
+      insert([[echo 'hello world']])
+      feed('!w<CR>')
+      local res = curbuf_contents()
+      eq(res, 'hello world')
+    end
+  end)
+
+  it('! should filter motion to &shell by default on startup but remember the change of {filter} program', function()
+    if not helpers.funcs.has('python3') then pending("missing `python3`") end
+    if not is_os('win') then
+      insert([[echo 'hello world';]])
+      feed('!w<CR>')
+      local res = curbuf_contents()
+      eq(res, 'hello world')
+      feed('ggdd')
+      insert([[print("coucou")
+if True:
+    print("Hello, Vimers")]])
+      feed('gg')
+      feed('!wpython3<CR>')

comment_data.body: Nice to have a test for this! Didn't know about this feature.

comment_data.body:
if you want to check partial match use `helpers.matches` .

```suggestion
      helpers.matches('Hi, coconut!', curbuf_contents())
```

Note: use `%` to escape things in Lua patterns. Hyphen is special in Lua patterns so it needs to be escaped to match a literal hypen.

comment_data.body: Thanks for reviewing this, I moved this part below as you suggested. However, I did that first because (again if I understood properly), in case the shell needs quote around the command, `newcmd` is set, and then may be executed as a filter program. I did that because the logic appeared simpler for me (I am sorry for the bad idea). However, in the current state of the code, shells that needs quotes are then not managed properly. I do not have an example for such a type of shells, and a web search did not return something. Do you, in any case, have an idea of a such a shell to test the code ? I thank you for your time.

Oh, it seems the `nvim` executable is not installed on the CI machines. Do you think it is a good idea to test with the compiled executable ? I will try this, to check the CI, but I am not sure if it is a good idea or not.

+      insert([[print("coucou")
+if True:
+    print("Hello, Vimers")]])
+      feed('gg')
+      feed('!wpython3<CR>')

comment_regular_data.body:
Hi, thank you very much for your comments @justinmk !
Thanks also for the hints ! I will add a tests for the Windows side of course. Would like this to work for `pwsh` also.

Hi, thank you very much for your comments and for your time.
I did not know about `xstrdup`, I am sorry for that, and I thank you for pointing it. 

There is a tricky part with the `prevcmd_is_set()` case, and it is more than possible that I misunderstood something. While working on the PR I discovered the normal mode commands `!!` and affiliates effectively set the global `bangredo` variable to `true`. However, the latter is not changed when the user inputs the `{range}!` command effectively, even though the normal command is a shortcut for writing the `{range}!` command. I have to admit, I did not understand the reason for this while investigating the code. I will dig further trying to come with a better refactor !
@justinmk The PR is ready for review, thank you very much in advance for your time !

Hey. Sorry for not giving this attention. It's an unfortunate reality of large-ish projects, it's nothing personal. Mind reopening this?

@justinmk please take a look at the PR of tou have time.

Hi, no offense at all! Managing such a project, and people around this project, is a full time job, I am happy you and other core members spend time on this editor!

I don't want to reopen this though (at least now). I had a look back at this (even very small) pr, to fix a merge conflict and the ci, and I realized I forgot a lot about it, the context and the solution I brought on the table, which appeared quite inelegant in fact. I may come back to this at some point, or it could serve as hint for others.

Thanks for your time!

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(cmd): pipe buffer to &shell with :!
